Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: James Bay Cree Visual Ethnographic Resource: Digitization of a Collection of a Photographic Archive from 1973
Award.AbstractNarration:
This EAGER project will contribute to the visual ethnographic and historical record of a Northern indigenous culture, the James Bay Cree in northern Quebec, Canada, through the digitization of a selection from a collection of over 2800 photographs taken in four coastal James Bay villages (Chisasibi, Wemindji, Eastmain and Waskaganish) in the summer of 1973. The images will be available through an online database, annotated with metadata describing the subject of the photographs. The intent is to provide access to the images to the Cree and science research communities to advance historical preservation and ethnographic research. It is envisioned that the digitization of the images in high-resolution quality will further increase circulation for a broad range of applications in media, publications, and exhibitions, contextualized according to a range of interests from indigenous history, ethnography, social research, and studies in visual communication, and the arts.

In addition to the digitization and repatriation portion of the project, the PI is collaborating with anthropologists to explore the cultural and social research opportunities that returning such historical photographs to the James Bay Cree Communities may generate. The visual materials will be returned through a scientific field trip to Wemindji, one of the four communities where the photographs were taken, and will be presented in public and in more intimate familial venues through slide shows followed by organized discussions. The first objective will be to identify individuals who were subjects of the images as a necessary step in creating the digital archive and facilitating social science analysis. The major tasks of this EAGER consist of 1) Scanning of contact sheets for discussion with ethnographers and selection of images from the inventory; 2) digitization of the images; 3) creation of an online database; 4) a scientific field trip to Wemindji, one of the four communities represented in the visual material to create community collaboration opportunities and to present the images and to annotate the images through community participation; 5) to test and document the multimedia presentation and repatriation process; 6) to integrate the metadata with the online visual database; and 7) and to verify the results through informal evaluations of user interactions with the database environment. This EAGER project is a unique opportunity for social scientists, visual commumications educators, and visual artists to collaborate with an indigenous community on repatriating images and memories in order to better understand the social significance of both.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF projcet has made it possible to create an online database that has public access for circulation of the images, I took in 1973. There has been significant changes going on in both the Cree culture (globalized cultural influence as everywhere else). All aspects of the proposed grant have been completed with significant other activities with the Cree such as circulation of the images in social media, upcoming book publications, discussions, upcoming exhibitions, etc. This is a project that has gained a life of its own and will continue to be active and create additional new events now that the images are accessible thanks to the NSF grant. This is the Outcomes Report: 

This project contributes to the visual ethnographic and historical record of four James Bay Cree Communities in sub-arctic, northern Quebec, Canada. The PI is collaborating with anthropologists to explore the cultural and social research opportunities that returning over 700 historical photographs taken by the PI in 1973 to the James Bay Cree Communities may generate. The PI has digitized and organized image collections into an online database titled “James Bay Ethnographic Resources”: http://tango.mat.ucsb.edu/jamesbay/

The collection of images includes a selection of 700 photographs from 2800 photographs taken by George Legrady in (Fort George, Wemindji, Eastmain and Waskaganish) in the summer of 1973. The collection also features photographs by indigenous photographers Mary B Georgekish and Beverly Mayappo. Also included are photographs by Miklos Legrady from 1973, anonymous photographs of an Oblate Mission in Wemindji, and video documentation taken in the summers of 2012 and 2014 during return trips to present and interview community members to provide descriptive information about the images. The return trips were done in collaboration with McGill University dept of Anthropology ethnographers Katherine Scott and Katie Sinclair. The intent is to provide access to the images to the Cree and academic research communities to advance historical preservation and ethnographic research.

The major tasks of this EAGER consist of 1) Scanning of contact sheets for discussion with ethnographers and selection of images from the inventory; 2) digitization of a selection of apprx 700 images; 3) creation of an online database; 4) 2 scientific field trip to 4 villages in James Bay, 5) to test and document the multimedia presentation and repatriation process; 6) to integrate the metadata with the online visual database; and 7) verify the results through informal evaluations of user interactions with the database environment, 8) Initiate analysis of the circulation of images once online.

Intellectual Merit: To provide access to the images to the Cree communities and academic research communities to advance historical preservation and ethnographic research.

Broader Impact: The collection of images provides visual documentation critical to cultural transformation analysis, ethnographic research, health condition comparisons to then and now. Accessbility to the images has resulted in informal circulation within the communities and outside through social network publications, and other forms of reporting.
